data.text: A rare celestial phenomenon involving the explosion of a star and resulting in an extremely bright, short-lived object that emits vast amounts of energy. Depending on the type of supernova, the explosion may completely destroy the star, or the stellar core may survive to become a neutron star.
data.attributionText: from The American HeritageÂ® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: A <xref>star</xref> which explodes, increasing its brightness to typically a billion times that of our <xref>sun</xref>, though attenuated by the great distance from our sun. Some leave only debris (Type I); others fade to <xref>invisibility</xref> as <xref>neutron stars</xref> (Type II).
data.attributionText: from Wiktionary, Creative Commons Attribution/Share-Alike License.

data.text: a star that explodes and becomes extremely luminous in the process
